name: Zion Canyon Scenic Drive
description: The most famous route in the park, this road follows the North Fork of the Virgin River through the deep Zion Canyon, offering views of the park's most iconic rock formations such as the Great White Throne.
tips: Personal vehicles are prohibited when the shuttle is running (March-November)
The shuttle is free and frequent, stopping at major trailheads

name: Hwy 9 from I-15 to Mt. Carmel Junction
description: This 54-mile scenic byway serves as the primary access to Zion National Park. The route winds past major landmarks, parallels the Virgin River, and traverses the park's famous mile-long tunnel and the unique Checkerboard Mesa area, connecting Interstate 15 to Highway 89.
tips: A fee is charged to drive through the park
Zion Canyon is accessible by shuttle only during the tourist season
Large vehicles and RVs are required to pay an escort fee for the Zion Tunnel
Can be driven as part of a loop returning via Hwy 14 or Hwy 89

name: Zion National Park Scenic Drive
description: A short drive along the canyon floor that features a narrow and deep canyon with sheer walls. It is the centerpiece of the park and offers views of landscape carved by the Virgin River.
tips: From March through November, personal vehicles are prohibited and the route is accessible only via the free Zion Canyon Shuttle.
Hazardous driving conditions may occur during and immediately following storms.
Icy spots remain on the road through the winter.

name: Zion-Mount Carmel Highway
description: An engineering marvel connecting the south and east entrances, featuring a mile-long tunnel and dramatic switchbacks with panoramic canyon views.
best_time: Golden hour for optimal light on the sandstone
tips: Large vehicles require a tunnel permit and ranger escort
Check vehicle size limits before driving

name: Kolob Canyons Road
description: A short but spectacular drive in the northwestern corner of the park, showcasing the stunning crimson 'fingers' of the Kolob Canyons.
tips: The road may be closed occasionally in winter due to snow

name: Kolob Reservoir Road
description: A scenic drive leading to the Kolob Reservoir, providing access to several interesting hiking trails and higher elevation views.
tips: This road involves a significant elevation gain of 5,085 ft.
Accesses more rugged, wilderness areas with fewer crowds.

name: Kolob Terrace Road
description: A high-altitude backcountry route starting in Virgin, Utah, providing a more remote perspective of Zion's landscape as it climbs toward the Kolob Reservoir.
tips: Road is not plowed in winter beyond a certain point
High elevation means cooler temperatures and changing weather

name: Zion Park Scenic Byway: Hurricane to Mt. Carmel Junction
description: An extensive scenic byway that connects Hurricane to Mt. Carmel Junction, passing through some of the park's most dramatic elevation changes.
tips: This route has the most elevation gain for scenic driving trails in the park at 5,390 ft.
Check weather conditions as high elevation passes can be affected by storms.
